title: Bitstar_coin
author: Bitstar_coin
content: Hello Guys! am excited to share my btc buy story with you today Okay, so I have been planning to change my old laptop for quite some time now (HP Folio 9470m - 4g ram, core i3 4th gen, 500g) which has served me well to be honest, am a light user so the spec was ok for my everyday office use. But I needed an upgrade and I was thinking of something mid-range and durable with a decent battery plus I need to change the brand so I did a little search and decided to go for Dell Latitude 7480 (corei7 7th gen, 8g ram, 256 ssd). I made plans to go hunting for one (pre-owned not brand new) and suddenly i thought, what about haunting the tech market in my local and see who among the traders has knowledge about btc and who will be willing to sell for BTC! the thought was appealing so I head downtown to haunt for a btc seller.Arriving at a section of the market where pre-owned gadgets are mostly sold, some sellers approach me and i told them am looking to buy a dell which they all have and i now said i am only paying in btc and they suddenly stop trying to get my attention, some of them said that "online money the government has banned"? nobody will sell for btc in this market, the rest ask what is btc? so i tried to explain just a bit to those who have not heard about btc what btc is but i was unsuccessful to convince them to accept btc. it is either fiat or nothing.I move to another section, ask a couple of them, still the same result then i saw a young guy across on the other side of the section and i approach him, told him what i want he hesitated for a while and so i ask if he is into crypto he said yes i smiled and knew i had to convince him, he said he has an account with Binance, owns some dogecoin because that's what his friend who introduces him to crypto bought for him.... was like really? lol.  I told him this is his opportunity to truly own the number one coin, I told him what he stands to gain if he sells for btc and held that btc in a couple of years. I gave instances of btc price history from previous years,  at the end of our little chit-chat, my guy was ready to get down to business.  We agreed on a price of $300 equivalent to my local currency. The transaction was pretty straightforward, i did a quick transfer of $300 BTC worth to his binance acct and within minutes he received notification of payment and the deal was sealed.He said he was actually thinking of buying a few btc but he has never used the binance p2p and he is not sure how to go about it, I showed him it was very easy, I did a quick p2p sale from my account and showed him all the process, he was really happy i could see his excitement because now he can buy on his own without relying on his friend to help him. I was glad to make my first physical buy with BTC and most of all impact more knowledge to a fellow crypto enthusiast, we shared contact and i promise to help him whenever he finds something unclear in his crypto journey.    And so i left with a smile on my face and my little companion               I have been using it for more than a week now and everything works great so far.

comments.author: Rruchi man
comments.body: Quote from: Bitstar_coin on July 29, 2022, 12:37:45 PMArriving at a section of the market where pre-owned gadgets are mostly sold, some sellers approach me and i told them am looking to buy a dell which they all have and i now said i am only paying in btc and they suddenly stop trying to get my attention, some of them said that "online money the government has banned"? nobody will sell for btc in this market, the rest ask what is btc? so i tried to explain just a bit to those who have not heard about btc what btc is but i was unsuccessful to convince them to accept btc. it is either fiat or nothing.That is a market place, where most of all those vendors must have met dubious individuals who may be have done fake transfers for them or someone they know so it is usually very scary for them to accept something they don't know as an exchange for goods they have. If i was in their shoes, I will exercise some skepticism as well if someone walks up to me offering to give me bitcoins for my goods. Also you have to understand that some are there to stack up money to be able to continue business, anything that is not cash seems a difficult process for them. You were lucky to have found someone to accept your bitcoins, but for ease next time only approach a vendor that clearly puts out a notice that they accept bitcoins if your intentions is to pay in bitcoins. Don't go around offering to pay for goods with crypto, it seems dubious.

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: Congratulations on your first successful purchase with Bitcoin, and I hope it won't be your last I haven't checked how much the new device costs, but it seems to be an older model laptop, although it has solid specifications for the average user. Personally, I always prefer to buy new devices because then I have a warranty, and I am at least somewhat sure that someone has not tampered with the hardware.I found an interesting video on YT about your device -> Dell Latitude 7480/7490: Watch before you buy used...

comments.author: coolcoinz
comments.body: It's sad that those sellers were treating bitcoin like it's some kind of dirty money. With online marketplaces it's always fine when you accept all their terms, but when you say "but I want this" the problems begin. They usually bail or don't want to accept it, or think like you're planning some sort of scam, even if it's some kind of little thing. I remember when we went to buy a car and we sat down and told the seller that everything's fine, but we want to pay half in a bank transfer and half in cash. It was nothing really, should be no issue whatsoever, but I remember the man and his wife exchange looks like "What do you think? Are they planning some scam? Any red flags?" People can act too suspicious sometimes when it comes to money.Anyway, congratulations on your purchase, may it work well and as long as you need it to.

comments.author: lovesmayfamilis
comments.body: Buying a used laptop is not a good idea. Yes, maybe it was cheaper, maybe it was almost new, but if you want to use it to work with bitcoin, you have a chance to lose your money.Reinstall the entire system, and format all drives, because if you use Windows, only one drive is formatted. But anyway, I'm quite pedantic about my devices. At any moment, any equipment from someone else's laptop can fail. Why did the owner sell it? Something didn't suit him, did it?Nowadays, even buying a new laptop can be dangerous. I would completely reinstall everything on a new one.But I hope you are doing well. Now save up for a new laptop.
